location: At the port
summary: 1/16/1996-1/20/1996: Nine Chechen Rebels hijacked a ferry as it was about to leave from the port in Trabzon, Trabzon, Turkey.  The 199 hostages on board were aboard Russian ferry bound for Sochi in Russia.  The rebels demanded that Russian forces stop their assault on the town of Pervomayskaya.  The incident was resolved without any loss of life and only one hostage being slightly wounded.  Nine men, including the leader of the group (Mohammed Tokan) were arrested and convicted.  No information on where the incident ended was available.
target1: Ferry bound for Russia from Turkey
motive: The group was protesting the on going assault on the Russian town of Pervomayskaya.  They demanded that the Russian government stop shelling the town.
ransomnote: The perpetrators demanded that Russians forces stop shelling the town of Pervomayskaya.
addnotes: The number of perpetrators ranges from 6 to 20.  Due to the fact that 9 were arrested and sentenced according to a 2001 report, the number of perpetrators is listed as 9.
scite1: "Chechens mount surprise assault on Russians: All hostages reportedly dead in rebel siege," CNN, January 18, 1996.
scite2: Carol J. Williams, "Chechen Rebels Stage New Raids," Los Angeles Times, January 17, 1996.
scite3: Carol J. Williams, "Russians Give Up on Hostages, Shell Chechens," Los Angeles Times, January 18, 1996.

target1: Police Guard at former PM. Cillers House
DeWayne Loomis, instructor at Incirlik AB

summary: 02/27/1998: Eight policemen were injured in a grenade attack from unknown perpetrators on a police station in Istanbul, Turkey. Besides hurling two grenades, the three unidentified assailants opened fire on the station in the Gaziosmanpasa district of the city. There were no fatalities in the attack.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Eight Policemen Injured in Istanbul Grenade Attack, Agence France Presse, February 27, 1998.
scite2: Istanbul Gendarmerie Station Attacked, 10 Gendarmes Wounded, Ankara TRT    Television Network, February 27, 1998.
scite3: Eight police injured in grenade attack in Istanbul, Agence France Presse, February 27,  1998.

summary: 04/10/1998: In Turkey, two members of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) threw a bomb into a park in Istanbuls tourist district, Sultanahment, while on a motorcycle. The explosion injured two Indian tourists, one New Zealander, four Turkish civilians, and two Turkish soldiers. Authorities arrested the two PKK perpetrators on April 12, 1998.
target1: Tourists at a park in Sultanahment District, Istanbul
target2: Civilians in a park in Sultanahment District, Istanbul
motive: Unknown
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001: A Chronology, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

summary: 05/12/1198: An assassination attempt was made against Human Rights Association (IHD) leader Akin Birdal in Ankara, Turkey. Two assailants, Bahri Eken and K.D, were believed to be operating under the direction of alleged gang leader Mahmut Yildirim (aka:"Yesil"). The two assailants shot Mr. Birdal after meeting with him. Mr. Birdal survived the attack.
target1: Akin Birdal, chairman of the Human Rights Association (IHD) in Ankara, Turkey
motive: To disturb the public order and stability in Turkey.
addnotes: Turkish Daily News Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz stated that the alleged gang leader Mahmut Yildirim, code-named "Yesil," was responsible for ordering the armed attack against Akin Birdal.
scite1: Human Rights Leader Birdal Identifies Assailants, Ankara Anatolia, May 24, 1998.
scite2: Yesil Behind Birdal Attack, Turkish Daily News, May 29, 1998.
scite3: Ahmet, Unal, Turkish Daily Reports on Attempt Against Birdal, Istanbul Zaman, May 14, 1998.

summary: 06/03/1998: Two unidentified male perpetrators threw a hand grenade at the Fatih Coffeehouse on Bayrampasa Cyprus Avenue in Kucukmece, Turkey. Six people were injured and the coffee house was damaged. Authorities suspected the involvement of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK)  in this attack. In addition to this attack, another bombing took place on a suburban train going from Sirkeci to Halkali.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The coffeehouse sustained some physical damage.
scite1: Hakan Aslaneli, A Day of Bombing, Turkish Daily News, June 5, 1998.

location: The incident occurred at the Yesilkoy train station
summary: 06/03/1998: A bomb exploded during rush hour on a suburban train going from Sirkeci to Halkali in Yesilkoy, Turkey. The bomb exploded in the first railway car as the train approached the Yesilkoy Station, killing one person and injuring four. AAuthorities suspected the involvement of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK)  in this attack. In addition to this attack, another bombing took place at a coffee shop in Kucukmece.
target1: Suburban train going from Sirkeci to Halkali
motive: Unknown
propcomment: A railway car was damaged.
scite1: Hakan Aslaneli, A Day of Bombing, Turkish Daily News, June 5, 1998.

summary: 08/29/1998: A bomb placed at the Motherland Party (ANAP) Bakirkoy District Center in Istanbul, Turkey, went off, slightly wounding a woman working at the center. No one claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: Unknown
scite1: One Slightly Wounded in Explosion at ANAP Istanbul Office, Ankara TRT Television Network, August 29, 1998.

summary: 09/09/1998: In one of two related attacks, rebels from the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) attacked the Imamli settlement unit in the village of Kuyucak, Turkey, killing one person and injuring three (Mustafa, Hilmi and Nuriye Atici). The perpetrators fled after this incident.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: This was one of two related cases (cf: [99809090001-2). This incident occurred despite the declaration of a cease-fire the previous week.
scite1: Terrorists Attack 2 Villages in Tokat; Kill Villager, Ankara Anatolia in English,  September 9, 1998.
scite2: "Terrorists" attack two villages in northeast, BBC Summary of World Broadcasts,  September 10, 1998.
scite3: Rebel Kurds attack Turkish villages despite ceasefire: report, Agence France Presse, September 9, 1998.

summary: 09/09/1998: In one of two related attacks, rebels from the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK)  attacked Gargin village in Turhal county, Turkey, killing one person (Hasan Bas). despite their declaration of a ceasefire. The perpetrators fled after this incident.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: This was one of two related cases (cf: [99809090001-2). This incident occurred despite the declaration of a cease-fire the previous week.
scite1: Terrorists Attack 2 Villages in Tokat; Kill Villager, Ankara Anatolia in English,  September 9, 1998.
scite2: "Terrorists" attack two villages in northeast, BBC Summary of World Broadcasts,  September 10, 1998.
scite3: Rebel Kurds attack Turkish villages despite ceasefire: report, Agence France Presse, September 9, 1998.

summary: 09/12/1998: Unidentified perpetrators attacked villagers who were working in a field in Akdana Village of Agri Province in Turkey, killing one person and injuring two others. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Terrorists Attack Villagers in Field in Agri, Kill One, Ankara Anatolia, September 12, 1998.
scite2: Anatolia News Agency Syas Kurds Kill Villager in Eastern Turkey, BBC Monitoring  Europe, September 12, 1998.

summary: 09/19/1998: Revolutionary Peoples Liberation Party-Front (DHKP-C) rebels fired a rocket shell at a police station in Istanbul, Turkey, causing material damage in the building, but no casualties.
motive: Unknown
scite1: MED TV -- DHKC Claims Responsibility for Istanbul Attack, London MED TV Television , September 19, 1998.
scite2: Istanbul police station hit in rocket attack, Agence France Presse, September 19, 1998.
scite3: Rocket damages Istanbul police station, The Associated Press, September 19, 1998.

summary: 10/04/1998: A group of perpetrators attacked two policemen on patrol in Tokat Province, Turkey. The policemen were injured and the police car was destroyed. The Turkish Workers and Peasant Liberation Army (TKP/ML-TIKKO) was suspected in this incident.
target1: Two Policemen on Patrol in Tokat Province, Turkey
motive: Unknown
propcomment: A police car was destroyed.
scite1: "Terrorists Injure 2 Policemen in Tokat Attack, Ankara Anatolia, October 5, 1998.

summary: 10/29/1998: Rebels of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) attacked the village of Baykoy, Turkey, killing one person. Local military soldiers who attempted to thwart the attack hit a landmine and six soldiers were injured.
target2: Turkish Defense Soldiers in Baykoy, Turkey
motive: Unknown
addnotes: This attack occurred on the 75th anniversary of the Turkish Republic.
scite1: Kurdish rebels attack village on Turkish state anniversary, 10 missing, Agence France Presse, October 30, 1998.
scite2: Village Guard Killed, 6 Soldiers Injured in Hakkari, Ankara Anatolia, October 30, 1998.

summary: 10/30/1998: An armed Kurdish militant hijacked an airplane in Ankara, Turkey. The plane was carrying 39 passengers and the hijacker demanded to fly to Switzerland. The pilot fooled the assailant into believing they had entered Bulgarian airspace and landed the plane at Ankaras Esenboga Airport. The plane was intercepted by local authorities and the assailant, a suspected member of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK), was killed. The hijacker said he was acting to protest against Turkeys crackdown on Kurdish rebels.
target1: Turkish Airlines Flight in Ankara, Turkey
motive: To protest the governments crackdown on the Kurds.
scite1: Andrei Palaria, Turkey Demands Hijacker Release Woman and Children, TASS, October 30, 1998.
scite2: "Hijacker Shot, Leicester Mercury, October 30, 1998.
scite3: "A Hijacker was shot Dead when Anti-terrorist Squads Raided a Turkish Airlines Flight Today after a Seven-hour Stand-off at Ankaras Airport, all 38 Passengers and Crew were Unharmed, Express & Echo, October 30, 1998.

location: This incident occurred at the Ozturk Recreation Center, located five km from Resadiye District.
summary: 10/30/1998: One unidentified female and seven unidentified male perpetrators used firearms to attack the Ozturk recreation center near Resadiye District, Turkey. The assailants fired shots at gasoline pumps, causing a fire. There were no casualties, but the center sustained some fire damage.
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Terrorists Attack Recreation Center in Tokat, Ankara Anatolia, October 31, 1998.

summary: 11/05/1998: A bomb exploded outside a prosecutors office at the judicial headquarters in Istanbul, Turkey, injuring two people. A woman called news outlets and claimed the attack on behalf of the Revolutionary Peoples Salvation Party-Front.
target1: Prosecutors office at the judicial headquarters in Istanbul, Turkey
motive: The attack was carried out to avenge four comrades who allegedly disappeared in police custody earlier in the week.
scite1: Explosion Hits Courthouse in Turkish Tourist Center, Injuring 2, The Associated Press, November 5, 1998.

summary: 11/06/1998: Four unidentified attackers threw a Molotov cocktail at a cafe in Dikbiyik, Samsun Province, Turkey. An assailant and security official were injured in the attack.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Firebomb Thrown at Samsun Café, 1 Assailant Killed, Ankara Anatolia, November 6, 1998.

location: This incident occurred on the outskirts of Gabar Mountain in the Kizilsu region.
summary: 11/10/1998: Suspected separatist militants killed six village guards and wounded seven others in an ambush on the outskirts of Gabar Mountain in the Kizilsu region of Sirnak Province, Turkey.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Terrorists Kill Six Village Guards, Wound Seven, Ankara Anatolia, November 10, 1998.

summary: 11/13/1998: Unidentified attackers threw a bomb at the Yapi Kredi Bank in the Eminonu District of Istanbul Province, Turkey. No casualties were reported, but the attack caused damage to the bank.
target1: Yapi Kredi Bank in Eminonu District of Istanbul Province, Turkey
motive: Unknown
scite1: No Casualties in Bomb Attack on Istanbul Bank, Ankara Anatolia, November 13, 1998.

summary: 11/17/1998: A female Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) suicide bomber detonated explosives strapped to her body near a military convoy at the Gendarmerie Command in Hakkaris Yuksekova District, Turkey. Five people, including four non-commissioned officers and a child, were injured in the explosion. The bomb was made of TNT mixed with bullets.
target1: Turkish Military Convoy at the Gendarmerie Command in Hakkari
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bomb was made of TNT mixed with bullets.
scite1: Six Injured in Hakkari Suicide Attack, Ankara Anatolia, November 17, 1998.
scite2: Female Suicide Attack in Hakkari; NCO, Child Wounded, Ankara Anatolia, November 17, 1998.

location: This incident occurred near Kirikkale.
summary: 11/27/1998: A bomb exploded on a bus near Kirikkale, Turkey. The explosion killed four passengers and injured 20 others. The bomb was placed in the luggage department of the bus. There was no claim of responsibility for this attack..
motive: Unknown
scite1: Four Killed, 20 Injured in Turkish Bus Explosion, Ankara - Turkish Daily News, November 28, 1998.

summary: 11/29/1998: The Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) was responsible for attacking a Turkish helicopter in an unspecified region in Turkey. Sixteen soldiers were killed, one injured, and one was missing. The attackers used firearms to bring the helicopter down. The PKK claimed responsibility for the crash in a statement carried by the pro-PKK agency, DEM.
motive: Unknown
scite1: PKK Shoots Down Turkish Helicopter, Agence France Presse, November 29, 1998.

summary: 12/01/1998: An 18-year-old female detonated a hand grenade she was carrying near a store on Ataturk Street, in the Lice District of Diyarbakir, Turkey. The blast killed the female and wounded at least eight others. Reports did not indicate whether the woman was affiliated with a group.
target1: Civilians on Ataturk Street, in the Lice District, Diyarbakir, Turkey.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The number of injured varied between sources, one claiming eight persons while the other claimed nine.
scite1: Bomber Killed, 8 Wounded in Explosion, Ankara Anatolia, December 1, 1998.
scite2: Suicide bomb kills one, injures nine in Turkey, Associated Press Worldstream, December 01, 1998.

summary: 12/24/1998: A female suicide bomber detonated a bomb in front of a military bus in Van, Turkey. The explosion damaged the bus, killed one and injured 22 others. Reports did not indicate whether the woman was a member of a group.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The bus was severely damaged.
scite1: Female Terrorist Carried Out Suicide Bombing in Van, Ankara Anatolia, December, 24, 1998.
scite2: One Person Killed, 22 Injured in Bomb Attack in Van, Anatolia, December, 24, 1998.

summary: 01/12/1999: Perpetrators threw a hand grenade at the MHP (Nationalist Action Party) election bureau in Uskudar, Turkey, injuring seven people. No organization claimed responsibility for the explosion, but on January 22, 1999 police reported the capture of Baki Alparslan, age 37, and Nazmi Gur, age 21, whom they claimed were responsible for the attack. Reports further stated that the perpetrators were part of an unnamed "separatist terrorist organization."
target1: MHP (Nationalist Action Party) election bureau in Uskudar, Turkey
motive: Unknown
scite1: Seven Hurt in Bombing of MHP Istanbul Bureau, Anatolia News Agency, January 12, 1999.
scite2: Two Terrorists Captured in Istanbul, Anatolia News Agency, January 22, 1999.

summary: 03/01/1999: Molotov cocktails were thrown at the Democratic Left Party headquarters in Bursa, Turkey, causing a fire, but no casualties. Supporters of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) were suspected in the attack.
target1: Democratic Left Party Headquarters in Bursa, Turkey
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were used in the attack.
propcomment: All furniture in the building was destroyed, and the inside of the building was damaged
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks during the month of March 1999 throughout Turkey, many of which occurred in Istanbul and/or involved Molotov Cocktails being thrown at the cars, political party offices, as well as at other building targets.
scite1: "Three Petrol Bombs Thrown at DSP Building in Bursa, Anatolia, March 1, 1999.

summary: 03/02/1999: Suspected members of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) attacked a Turkish Army patrol in the Seyhan District of Adana Province, Turkey, killing one and injuring five.
motive: Unknown
scite1: One Killed, 5 Injured in Mardin Terrorist Attack 2 Mar, Anatolia, March 3, 1999.

summary: 03/03/1999: Unidentified assailants threw Molotov cocktails at a car in the parking lot of the Directorate General of Monopoly in the Unkapani district of Istanbul, Turkey. The car and offices were damaged in the attack.
target1: Car in parking lot of Directorate General of Monopoly offices
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were used in the attack.
propcomment: The car was severely damaged and there was minor damage to the Directorate offices.
addnotes: This was one of six related attacks (cf. 199903030003, 199903030005-8, 199903040002). These were also among a number of attacks during the month of March 1999 throughout Turkey, many of which occurred in Istanbul and/or involved Molotov Cocktails being thrown at the cars, political party offices, as well as at other building targets.
scite1: AA Reports on Petrol Bomb Attacks in Istanbul,  Anatolia, March 4, 1999.

summary: 03/03/1999: Unidentified perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail at a car in Zeytinburnu district, Istanbul, Turkey.
target1: Civilian car  in Zeytinburnu district in Istanbul, Turkey
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were used in the attack.
propcomment: The car was damaged by the fire.
addnotes: This was one of six related attacks (cf. 199903030003, 199903030005-8, 199903040002). These were also among a number of attacks during the month of March 1999 throughout Turkey, many of which occurred in Istanbul and/or involved Molotov Cocktails being thrown at the cars, political party offices, as well as at other building targets.
scite1: AA Reports on Petrol Bomb Attacks in Istanbul, Anatolia, March 4, 1999.

summary: 03/03/1999: Unidentified perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail at a car that was parked in front of the Istanbul Water and Sewage Administration (ISKI) in Zeytinburnu district, Istanbul, Turkey. The car sustained minor damage in that attack.
target1: Civilian car in front of Istanbul Water and Sewage Administration
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were used in the attack.
propcomment: The car suffered minor damage.
addnotes: This was one of six related attacks (cf. 199903030003, 199903030005-8, 199903040002). These were also among a number of attacks during the month of March 1999 throughout Turkey, many of which occurred in Istanbul and/or involved Molotov Cocktails being thrown at the cars, political party offices, as well as at other building targets.
scite1: AA Reports on Petrol Bomb Attacks in Istanbul, Anatolia, March 4, 1999.

summary: 03/03/1999: Unidentified perpetrators threw Molotov cocktails at a car in Besiktas district, Istanbul, Turkey. The car sustained minor damage in the attack.
target1: Civilian car in Besiktas district, Istanbul, Turkey.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were used in the attack.
propcomment: The car suffered minor damage.
addnotes: This was one of six related attacks (cf. 199903030003, 199903030005-8, 199903040002). These were also among a number of attacks during the month of March 1999 throughout Turkey, many of which occurred in Istanbul and/or involved Molotov Cocktails being thrown at the cars, political party offices, as well as at other building targets.
scite1: AA Reports on Petrol Bomb Attacks in Istanbul, Anatolia, March 4, 1999.

summary: 03/03/1999: A bomb that was left in front of Is Bankasi, a private bank in Beyoglu district, Istanbul, Turkey, was disarmed by the bomb squad. No further information was provided on this incident, and the perpetrators were unknown.
target1: Is Bankasi Bank in Beyoglu district of Istanbul
motive: Unknown
addnotes: This was one of six related attacks (cf. 199903030003, 199903030005-8, 199903040002). These were also among a number of attacks during the month of March 1999 throughout Turkey, many of which occurred in Istanbul and/or involved Molotov Cocktails being thrown at the cars, political party offices, as well as at other building targets.
scite1: AA Reports on Petrol Bomb Attacks in Istanbul, Anatolia, March 4, 1999.

summary: 03/04/1999: A Kurdish female suicide bomber detonated a bomb in the Batman, Turkey, main square, killing herself and causing property damage to the surrounding area. There were three others wounded in the attack as well. The Peoples Liberation Army of Kurdistan (ARGK) claimed responsibility for the attack. A press statement stated that the bomber was Ms. Nezahat Boyaci.
motive: The attack was to protest the arrest of PKK leader Abdallah Ocalan by Turkish forces.
propcomment: Buildings around the main square were damaged.
scite1: "Suicide Terrorist Killed, 3 Persons Wounded in Batman, Anatolia, March 4, 1999
scite2: "ARGK To Escalate Attacks, Claims Responsibility on Batman, MED TV Television, March 5, 1999.

summary: 03/04/1999: Unidentified perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail at a car in Beyoglu district, Istanbul, Turkey. The car sustained minor damage in the attack.
target1: Civilian car in Beyoglu district, Istanbul, Turkey
motive: Unknown

summary: 03/05/1999: A car bomb attack targeted the Cankiri Provincial Governor, Ayhan Cevik, while he was driving in Cankiri, Turkey. Four people were killed and the Governor and nine others were wounded. The Turkish Workers and Peasants Liberation Army (TKP/ML-TIKKO) claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: To assassinate the Governor.
weapdetail: The car bomb was detonated by remote.
propcomment: The surrounding area was damaged, but not seriously.

scite2: "Turkey Governor Attack by Leftist Group: Police, Xinhua News Agency, March 5, 1999.
scite3: "Two Suspects in Cankiri Attack Arrested, 4th Victim Dies, TRT Television Network, March 14, 1999.

summary: 03/10/1999: A car bomb killed one and injured eight in neighborhood of Bekirkoy, Istanbul. No one claimed responsibility for this attack.
target1: Civilians in Bekirkoy neighborhood, Istanbul, Turkey
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bomb was in a taxi.
propcomment: The taxi was destroyed.

scite1: Taxi Bomb Kills Driver, Injures Eight People in Istanbul, St. Louis Post-Dispatch, March 11, 1999.

summary: 03/11/1999: Sahin Huseyin, a member of the Peoples Liberation Army of Kurdistan (ARGK), carried out a suicide bombing at the MIT (Turkish Intelligence Organization) in Dahuk, Turkey. Huseyin shot four security guards outside and detonated his explosives once inside the building. Two MIT officials were killed and six were wounded in the incident. The ARGK claimed responsibility in a statement, saying the attack was in response to the arrest of Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) leader Abdullah Ocalan.
motive: The attack was in response to the arrest of PKK leader Abdullah Ocalan.
scite1: ARGK Suicide Bombing in Dahuk Kills Two MIT Officials, MED TV, March 11, 1999.

summary: 03/13/1999: Molotov cocktails were thrown into the Blue Market shopping center in the Kadikoy region of Istanbul, Turkey, killing thirteen and wounding six. No one had claimed responsibility for the attack, but the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) was suspected.
target1: Blue Market shopping center in the Kadikoy region of Istanbul, Turkey
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The store was damaged by fire.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks during the month of March 1999 throughout Turkey, many of which occurred in Istanbul and/or involved Molotov Cocktails being thrown at the cars, political party offices, as well as at other building targets.
scite1: Istanbul Governor Warns Citizens of Continuing Attacks, Anatolia, March 13, 1999.
scite2: More Istanbul Bombs stoke terror fears, The Australian, March 16, 1999.
scite3: 13 people killed, six wounded in explosion in Istanbul, Xinhua News Agency, March 13, 1999

location: This incident occurred in Batman Province.

Missile launchers and automatic weapons were used in the attack. There were no casualties, but some oil tankers at the station were hit.

motive: Unknown

motive: Unknown
propcomment: Two cars in the area were damaged.

summary: 03/18/1999: Two unnamed perpetrators were caught after they threw a petrol bomb at the office of a Mayoral candidate from the Nationalist Movement Party (MHP) in Mus, Turkey. The bomb started a fire, but caused only minor damage before it was extinguished. Reports did not state whether the perpetrators acted on behalf of a group.
target1: Nationalist Movement Party Mayoral candidate office in Mus, Turkey
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were used in the attack.

summary: 03/20/1999: A suicide bomber wounded two police officers and a bystander as he approached a police station in Diyarbakir, Turkey. The Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) was suspected of this attack.
motive: Unknown
scite1: 3 Hurt in Suicide Bombing in Turkey, Associated Press Online, March 20, 1999.

location: This incident occurred in Sirnak Province.
summary: 03/20/1999: A female suicide bomber attempted to detonate her device in Sirnak province, Turkey, but was arrested before she was successful. The Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) was suspected in this attempt. The target of the attack was not identified in the reports.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Two grenades were strapped to the bombers body.
scite1: 3 Hurt in Suicide Bombing in Turkey, Associated Press Online, March 20, 1999.

summary: 03/21/1999: The Peoples Liberation Army of Kurdistan (ARGK) Metropolitan Revenge Brigade claimed responsibility for a bomb attack in Van, Turkey. There were no casualties, but the bomb destroyed a power transformer and damaged an administration building.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The power transformer was destroyed, and an administration building nearby was damaged.
scite1: ARGK Revenge Brigade Claims Responsibility for Van Bomb, MED TV, March 21, 1999.

location: This incident occurred in Mardin Province.
summary: 03/21/1999: The Peoples Liberation Army of Kurdistan (ARGK) claimed responsibility for a bomb that targeted an oil pipeline in Mardin Province, Turkey. This attack caused a section of the pipeline from Iraq to be blocked for a day.
target1: Turkish Petroleum Corporation (TPAO) oil pipeline in Mardin Province, Turkey
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The pipeline was out of operation for one day.
scite1: PKK Claims Responsibility for Iraqi Pipeline Blast, Agence France Presse (North European Service), March 23, 1999.

summary: 03/23/1999: Unknown perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail at the Nationalist Movement Party (MHP) election office in Maltepe District, Istanbul, Turkey. The office sustained only minor damage and there were no casualties.
target1: Nationalist Movement Party election office in Maltepe District, Istanbul, Turkey
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were used in the attack.
propcomment: There was minor fire damage to the outside of the office.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks during the month of March 1999 throughout Turkey, many of which occurred in Istanbul and/or involved Molotov Cocktails being thrown at the cars, political party offices, as well as at other building targets.
scite1: Molotov Cocktail Hurled at MHP Office in Istanbul, Anatolia, March 24, 1999.

summary: 03/26/1999: Three policemen and seven bystanders were injured by a suicide bomber in Taksim District, Istanbul, Turkey. The female bomber detonated two hand grenades, and security forces disarmed three others, which did not detonate. The bombing occurred near a bus belonging to security forces. The Kurdistan Peoples Liberation Army (ARGK) claimed responsibility for the attack through DEM, a pro-Kurdish news agency.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bomber had grenades strapped to her body. Two detonated, but three did not and were disarmed by police.
scite1: Number of Injured in Istanbul Suicide Bombing Reaches 10, Anatolia, March 27, 1999.
scite2: PKK Claims Responsibility for Istanbul bombing, Agence France Presse, March 28, 1999.

summary: 03/27/1999: Molotov cocktails were thrown at two cars in Zeytinburnu District, Istanbul, Turkey. The perpetrators of this incident were not identified.
target1: Two civilian cars in Zeytinburnu District, Istanbul, Turkey
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were used in the attack.
propcomment: The two cars sustained some fire damage.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks during the month of March 1999 throughout Turkey, many of which occurred in Istanbul and/or involved Molotov Cocktails being thrown at the cars, political party offices, as well as at other building targets.
scite1: "Two Cars Firebombed in Istanbul, No Casualties, Anatolia, March 27, 1999.

summary: 03/27/1999: Seven people were wounded when two perpetrators threw a bag of explosives at riot police in Istanbul, Turkey. One of the perpetrators was killed in the attack. Following the bombing, police questioned whether the attack was a suicide bombing. No group claimed responsibility for this attack.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks during the month of March 1999 throughout Turkey, many of which occurred in Istanbul and/or involved Molotov Cocktails being thrown at the cars, political party offices, as well as at other building targets.
scite1: Turkey-Bomb, Broadcast News (BN), March 27, 1999.

summary: 03/28/1999: A bomb was set off under a car in front of the National Action Party election office in Zeytinburnu District, Istanbul, Turkey. The office and surrounding area sustained minor damage, but there were no casualties. The perpetrators of this incident were not identified
target1: Nationalist Action Party (MHP) office in Istanbul, Turkey
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The car that the bomb was placed under was damaged, and some buildings had their windows broken.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks during the month of March 1999 throughout Turkey, many of which occurred in Istanbul and/or involved Molotov Cocktails being thrown at the cars, political party offices, as well as at other building targets.
scite1: Bomb Explosion in Istanbul Causes Financial Damage, Anatolia, March 29, 1999.

summary: 03/30/1999: Five people were injured in an armed attack on the Virtue Party (FP) District Chairmanship in Of, Turkey. Two people entered the building and began firing randomly. One assailant, Husnu Bak, was captured, and the other was identified as Rahmi Yagli.
target1: Virtue Party District Chairmanship in Turkey
motive: Unknown
scite1: Five Injured in Armed Attack on FP Building, Anatolia, March 30, 1999.

summary: 04/03/1999: A suicide bomber named Cenan Akgun detonated an explosive device in the in Erdemli quarter of Marcik, in the Tunceli Province of Turkey. There were no casualties except the bomber who died. It was possible that the bomb exploded prematurely.
motive: Unknown
scite1: No Casualties in Suicide Bombing in Tunceli, Anatolia, April 4, 1999.

summary: 04/05/1999: A suicide bomber from the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK), identified as Baki Tatli, targeted Bingol Governor Suleyman Kamci using an explosive device in the Bingol province of Turkey. Two were killed, the bomber and a teenage girl, but the governor escaped unharmed.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Governor: Suicide Bombing Sought To Disrupt Tranquillity, Anatolia, April 7, 1999.
scite2: Bilican Says Suicide Bomb Shows Collapse of Terrorists, Anatolia, April 6, 1999.
scite3: Agence France Presse: PKK Claims Responsibility for Bingol Suicide Bombing, Agence France Presse (North European Service), April 6, 1999.

summary: 04/08/1999: An Iranian suicide bomber, identified as Turab Muhammedi, attacked Hakkari Governor Nihat Canpolat. The suicide bomber and Canpolats driver both died, while Canpolat, his bodyguard, Colonel Tahir Cebi, and two passersby were injured. Five men, two Iranians and three Turks were arrested for participating in the suicide bombing.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The other perpetrators arrested were Mecit Beduzade (Fuat), Hekim Pirpence (Cello), Cengiz Buyuksu, Cimsit Bala, and Hasan Bala.
scite1: Governor Back in Hakkari, Perpetrator Still Unidentified, Anatolia, April 8, 1999.
scite2: Terrorists Explain Suicide Bombing Plan in Hakkari, Anatolia, April 9, 1999.
scite3: Governor on Hakkari Suicide Bombing, Perpetrators, Anatolia, April 9, 1999.

summary: 04/09/1999: In the Yenimahalle District of Turkey, unknown persons fired shots at the minibus of Democratic Left Party s (DSP) candidate for mayor, Leman Canbol. Three people were slightly injured by broken glass.
target1: A campaign bus of Democratic Left Party (DSP) candidate, Leman Canbol touring the Yenimahalle district
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Windows on the bus were broken.
scite1: Shots Fired at DSP Election Minibus, 3 Slightly Injured, Anatolia, April 9, 1999.

location: This incident occurred near Osmaniye.
summary: 04/11/1999: Three soldiers and a civilian were killed when a bomb exploded near the town of Osmaniye, Turkey. Authorities believed that this incident was the work of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK).
target1: An army patrolling near the Osmaniye
motive: Unknown
scite1: Four killed in bomb blast in southern Turkey, Agence France Presse, April 11, 1999.
scite2: Kurdish rebels detonate bomb as Ocalan renews cease-fire call, The Associated Press, April 11, 1999.
scite3: Report: Kurds Kill Four in Turkey, Associated Press Online, April 11, 1999.

summary: 04/16/1999: In Turkey, an explosive device planted by unknown perpetrators caused damage to the Virtue Party election bureau in the Istanbul suburb of Maltepe.
target1: The election bureau of the Virtue Party in Maltepe, Turkey
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Some damage was caused to the building.
scite1: Bomb Hurled at FP Election Bureau Causes Damage, Anatolia, April 16, 1999.

summary: 04/17/1999: Heavily armed members of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) attacked and destroyed a radio and television station of the TRT network in Akai, Turkey, killing one and injuring one.
target1: The TRT network radio and television station in Akai, Turkey
motive: Unknown
scite1: PKK Guerrillas Destroy Turkish Radio-TV Station, IRNA, April 19, 1999.

summary: 04/18/1999: An unknown group, armed with grenades, tried to enter Bingol, Turkey, in order to disrupt the local elections. Two perpetrators were killed by security forces in the attempt.
motive: The purpose of the attack was aimed at disrupting the Bingol local elections.
addnotes: Two of the perpetrators were killed and an unknown number escaped.
scite1: 2 Terrorists Planning To Sabotage Elections Killed, Anatolia, April 18, 1999.

summary: 05/06/1999: Unknown perpetrators opened fire on soldiers-on-duty in the Gendermarie Commandership in the Yuksekova District of Hakkari Province, Turkey. One fatality and four injuries resulted from this attack.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Turkish Security Forces launched an operation after the attack to find the perpetrators. They reportedly took several people into custody who were suspected to have participated in the shooting. Further information on the suspects was not available.
scite1: "Soldier Killed, 4 Injured in Yuksekova Terrorist Attack," Anatolia, May 7, 1999.

summary: 05/12/1999: Unknown perpetrators attacked a maintenance house, which belonged to the Directorate General of Rural Affairs, killing the watchman on duty.
corp1: Turkish Directorate General of Rural Affairs
target1: The Rural Affairs maintenance house near Cat County
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The attackers did not try to destroy the building.
addnotes: The perpetrators chanted separatist propaganda and slogans during the attack. Local law enforcement pursued the perpetrators after the attack. During the ensuing battle, five perpetrators were killed along with two more policemen.
scite1: "Terrorists Kill Watchman, Wound 4 in Erzurum," Anatolia, May 12, 1999.

location: This incident occurred near the town of Mesudiye.
summary: 05/15/1999: Unknown perpetrators ambushed a military vehicle belonging to the Gendarme Commandership near the town of Mesudiye in northern Turkey near the Black Sea. During the attack, three Turkish soldiers were killed and another was wounded.
target1: A vehicle carrying soldiers belonging to the Turkish Gendarme Commandership
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The attacks coincided with the detainment of then Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) leader, Abdullah Ocalan.
scite1: "3 soldiers killed in northern turkey, Xinhua News Agency, May 15, 1999.

summary: 05/18/1999: Perpetrators suspected of belonging to the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) planted a mine that detonated when a Turkish military vehicle passed by along a road near to the Ozluce Dam in Karakoan, Turkey. The explosion injured five military personnel including one officer.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The mine exploded as the vehicle passed nearby.
addnotes: Although no group claimed responsibility for the attacks, Turkish officials suspected the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) because they had been active in southeastern Turkey during the time of the attack. Abdullah Ocalan, the PKKs leader, had been captured and detained by Turkish security forces on charges of treason in February 1999.
scite1: 5 military personnel wounded in explosion in turkey, Xinhua News Agency, May 18, 1999.

summary: 06/02/1999: Two unidentified assailants hurled one or two hand grenades at the outer door of Masal Evi Bar in the Kadikoy District of Turkey. Patri Klein, a German citizen, and his wife, Sureyya Klein, sustained minor injuries and minor property damage occurred as well. Turkish authorities detained a number of suspects following the explosion and early reports indicated that an Islamic fundamentalist organization was responsible for the attack, but no further information was provided on the perpetrators.
target1: Masal Evi bar in Kadikoy District
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The bar sustained minor damage.
addnotes: Sources differed on the date of this attack, though most of the articles reported June 2nd, as recorded here.
scite1: "Hand Grenades Hurled at Istanbul Pub," Anatolia, June 3, 1999.
scite2: "Two lightly injured in bomb attack in Istanbul," Agence France Presse, June 9, 1999.
scite3: "Bar Bombed in Kadikoy," Turkish Daily News, June 4, 1999.

summary: 06/16/1999: In the Diyadin District of Agri Province, Turkey, a group of perpetrators attacked the gendarme post at the entrance to the District, as well as security and municipal buildings, with missiles and rifles. Two of the perpetrators were killed in the attack, which caused no additional casualties. The municipal buildings were also damaged in the attack.
target2: Unnamed security buildings in Diyadin District
target3: Unnamed municipal government buildings in Diyadin District
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Municipal buildings were damaged in the attack.
addnotes: Further details on the security and government buildings attacked were not available.
scite1: "Terrorists Attack Agri District With Missiles," Anatolia, June 17, 1999.

summary: 06/17/1999: Two unidentified armed assailants attacked and killed Ramazan Sagir, a former leader of the True Path Party (DYP) of Selcuklu District from 1996-97, as he emerged from his house on Rauf Denktas Boulevard in Konya, Selcuklu district, Turkey. Sagir died at the scene.
target1: Ramazan Sagir, former True Path Party (DYP) leader
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Former DYP District Official Killed in Armed Attack," Anatolia, June 17, 1999.

summary: 06/20/1999: A group of unidentified perpetrators with shotguns attacked the home of Kiziltepe District Governor Mesut Yildirim on Senyurt Boulevard in Kiziltepe district, Mardin province, Turkey. Eight security officers were wounded in the attack, though there were no casualties.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The injured security officers included Sahin Karasakal, Suleyman Kacar, Savas Karabulut, Baykara Ozcan, Serhan Unlu, Hasan Guler, Bulent Kurtalan, and Irfan Turkoglu.
scite1: "8 Injured in Terrorist Attack on Governors Lodgings," Anatolia, June 21, 1999.

location: This incident occurred on Bayrak Hill.
summary: 06/25/1999: The Peoples Liberation Army of Kurdistan (ARGK) bombed Bayrak Hill in Turkey, which controls the security of Beytussebap and where officers are positioned, with heavy weapons and bombs. Eight Turkish Army soldiers were killed and nine others were wounded in the attack.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: It was reported that some of the injuries might have been the result of friendly fire, as Turkish Army soldiers hit other soldiers who were fleeing from the hill, mistaking them for guerillas.
scite1: "Eight Soldiers Said Killed, 9 Wounded in ARGK Attack," Neu-Isenburg Ozgur Politika (Internet version), June 26, 1999.

summary: 07/01/1999: Nevzat Kur and Sukriye Yilmaz, members of the Peoples Liberation Army of Kurdistan (ARGK), assumed responsibility for an armed attack on a coffee house in central Elazig, Turkey. The attack killed eight, including Idealist Club members and two perpetrators, and wounded five civilians. The degree of damage resulting from the incident was not reported.
target1: Idealist Club members at Coffee Shop in Elazig, Turkey
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Those killed included Ferhan Bulut, Sukru Tuna, Idris Yeter, and Bilal Comert and those injured were Levent Gunhan, Murat Cicek, Mehmet Orhan, Nihat Arslan, and Mustafa Demirci.
scite1: ARGK Claims Responsibility for Elazig Attack, Rayleigh CTV Television, July 5, 1999.
scite2: "Rebel Kills Three in Coffee House, Toronto Star, July 2, 1999.
scite3: "Five Killed, 5 Injured in Elazig Terrorist Attack, Ankara Anatolia, July 1, 1999.

location: This incident occurred along the road between Sirnak Provinces Guclukonak and Cizre Districts.
summary: 07/03/1999: Peoples Liberation Army of Kurdistan (ARGK) guerrillas attacked a military unit that was guarding the road between Sirnaks Guclukonak and Cizre Districts. Seven soldiers, including one officer, were killed and five soldiers were wounded in the attack.
target1: Turkish Military Unit, guarding the road between Sirnaks Guclukonak and Cizre, Districts, Turkey
motive: The attack was in protest of Abdullah Ocalans recent sentencing in a Turkish court.
scite1: ARGK Kills 15 Soldiers Outside Sirnak, Midyat, Eruh, Neu-Isenburg Ozgur Politika, July 5, 1999.

summary: 07/03/1999: Peoples Liberation Army of Kurdistan (ARGK) guerrillas ambushed soldiers from the BOTAS Petroleum Pipeline Corporation police station who were guarding the pipeline near Mardins Midyat District in Cayirli, Turkey. Five soldiers were killed and two were wounded from the attack.
target1: BOTAS Petroleum Pipeline Corporation Police Station in Cayirli, Turkey
motive: The attack was in protest of Abdullah Ocalans recent sentencing in a Turkish court.
scite1: ARGK Kills 15 Soldiers Outside Sirnak, Midyat, Eruh, Neu-Isenburg Ozgur Politika, July 5, 1999.

summary: 07/04/1999: A powerful homemade shrapnel bomb fitted with a timer was left in a garbage bin and exploded in a park in Istanbul, Turkey. The explosion killed one person and wounded 25 others. Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) was suspected in the attack, but its leadership denied responsibility.
targsubtype1_txt: Public Area (garden, parking lot, garage, beach, public building, camp)
target1: Civilians in a Park in Istanbul, Turkey
motive: The attack was in protest of Abdullah Ocalans recent sentencing in a Turkish court.
scite1: "Authorities Urge Vigilance after Fatal Istanbul Bomb Blast, Agence France Presse, July 5, 1999.

summary: 07/04/1999: A tanker truck belonging to the government-owned Turkish Petroleum Corporation hit a landmine planted by suspected Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) rebels in Batman province, Turkey. The attack injured 4 and killed the driver of the vehicle, which was badly damaged from the explosion.
target1: Turkish Petroleum Corporation (TPAO) Tanker Truck in Batman Province, Turkey
motive: The attack was in protest of Abdullah Ocalans recent sentencing in a Turkish court.
scite1: "1 Killed, 10 Injured in Landmine Explosions in Turkey, Xinhua, July 5, 1999
scite2: "Driver of Vehicle Dies after Hitting Mine in Batman, Ankara Anatolia, July 5, 1999.

summary: 07/05/1999: Ms. Rusen Tabanci, a 19-year-old female Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) member, detonated a bomb strapped to her body outside of a police station in Adana, Turkey. The suicide bomber was killed and seventeen others were injured in this attack. The area sustained minor damage.
target1: The Turkish Police Force Station in Adana, Turkey
motive: The attack was in protest of Abdullah Ocalans recent sentencing in a Turkish court.
scite1: "Suicide Attack near Police Station Injures 17 in Turkey, The Associated Press, July 6, 1999.
scite2: "Kurdish Rebel Blamed in Blast, Hamilton Spectator, July 6, 1999.
scite3: "Suicide Bomb Attack Injures 17 in Turkey; Assailant called Kurdish Woman, 19, The Boston Globe, July 6, 1999.

location: The landmine was planted near Uzumlu.
summary: 07/05/1999: A land mine which was planted by Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) members, exploded when a minibus hit it near Uzumlu village in Hakkari province, Turkey. The explosion caused minor damage to the area, killed one person and injured five others.
target1: Passengers on a minibus near Uzumlu, Turkey
motive: The attack was in protest of Abdullah Ocalans recent sentencing in a Turkish court.
scite1: "1 Killed, 10 Injured in Landmine Explosions in Turkey, Xinhua, July 5, 1999.
scite2: "Minibus Hits Landmine in Hakkari, 1 Killed, 5 Injured, Ankara Anatolia, July 5, 1999.

location: This incident occurred near Cayirli.
summary: 07/07/1999: Two soldiers were killed when a group of unidentified men using long-barreled guns and rocket launchers attacked a military convoy near Cayirli village in Hakkari province, Turkey. The area sustained minor damage in the attack.
target1: Turkish Armed Forces convoy on patrol near Cayirli village.
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Two Soldiers Killed in Terrorist Attack in Hakkari, Ankara Anatolia, July 7, 1999.

summary: 07/08/1999: A time bomb planted under a fuel tanker exploded in the Esenler district of Istanbul province, Turkey. There were no casualties, but damage occurred to the fuel tanker and nearby vehicles. No group claimed credit for this attack.
target1: Fuel Tanker Truck in Esenler District, Turkey
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Bomb Under Fuel Tanker Causes No Casualties in Istanbul, Ankara Anatolia,  July 9, 1999.

summary: 07/09/1999: A unknown group attacked a construction site owned by the Ercan Mining company in the Payas township of Hatays Dortyol District, Turkey. There were no casualties, but the perpetrators set three vehicles on fire.
target1: Ercan Mining Company Construction Site in Payas Township, Turkey
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Terrorists Attack Construction Site, Burn Vehicles, Ankara Anatolia, July 9, 1999.

summary: 07/11/1999: Unknown attackers used firearms and incendiary devices to attack a construction site belong to the Highway Regional Directorate in Sivas Dogansar District, Turkey. Two men were killed and minor property damage occurred in the attack.
target1: Highway 16th Regional Directorate construction site in Sivas, Turkey
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Shotguns and incendiary materials were used in the attack.
scite1: "Terrorists Attack Construction Site, Kill 2, Ankara Anatolia, July 12, 1999.

summary: 07/12/1999: Two people were critically injured in a bomb that exploded on a minibus in Istanbul, Turkey. The bus was damaged from the explosion. Turkish authorities believed that the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) was responsible for the attack.
motive: The attack was in protest of Abdullah Ocalans recent sentencing in a Turkish court.
scite1: "Two Hurt in Istanbul Blast as Police Arrest Suspected PKK Rebels, Agence France Presse, July 13, 1999.
scite2: "AA Reports More Details on Istanbul Explosion, Ankara Anatolia,  July 12, 1999.

summary: 07/14/1999: Members of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) were suspected of killing five villagers in a southeastern province of Erzincan, Turkey. The attack occurred when assailants opened fired on villagers traveling by tractor on a country road.
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Terrorists Kill 4 Civilians in Erzincan, Ankara Anatolia, July 14, 1999.
scite2: "Suspected Kurdish Rebels Kill Five, The Associated Press, July 15, 1999.

summary: 07/14/1999: A firebomb was thrown at a service bus in Esenler district, Istanbul, Turkey. There were no reported casualties in the attack, although the vehicle was damaged. The bus was owned by the Servet Tourism Company and was one of two buses attacked on this day. No group or individual claimed credit for this attack.
target1: Servet Tourism Company Bus in Istanbul, Turkey
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The bus sustained fire damage.
scite1: "Firebombs Thrown at Istanbul Buses Causing Damage, Ankara Anatolia, July 14, 1999.

summary: 07/14/1999: A firebomb was thrown at a service bus in Esenler district, Istanbul, Turkey. There were no reported casualties in the attack, although the vehicle was damaged. The bus was owned by the Servet Tourism Company and was one of two buses attacked on this day. No group or individual claimed credit for this attack.
target1: Servet Tourism Company Bus in Istanbul, Turkey
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The bus sustained fire damage.
scite1: "Firebombs Thrown at Istanbul Buses Causing Damage, Ankara Anatolia, July 14, 1999.

location: This incident occurred in Sirnak Province on Gabar Mountain.
summary: 07/15/1999: Peoples Liberation Army of Kurdistan (ARGK) guerrillas attacked the Turkish Radio and Television (TRT) building in Sirnak province, Turkey. Two village guards and three soldiers were killed in the ensuing clash. Damage was not reported in this incident.
target1: Turkish Radio and Television (TRT) Building on Gabar Mountain, Turkey
motive: Unknown
scite1: "11 Soldiers, 18 KDP Members Said Killed by ARGK, Ozgur Politika, July17, 1999.

summary: 07/20/1999: Unidentified perpetrators opened fire on an open-air cafe in Caglayan, Turkey, killing one person and wounding seven others. The café sustained minor damage in the attack.
target1: Civilians in a cafe in Caglayan, Turkey
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Terrorists Fire on Cafe in Erzincan, Killing One, Ankara Anatolia, July 21, 1999.

summary: 07/20/1999: One person died and seven were injured when unidentified perpetrators opened fired on a cafe in Arabaslik, Turkey. The café was damaged and no one was arrested in connection with the attack.
target1: Civilians in a cafe in Caglayan District, Turkey
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Abidin Irmak, 49, was killed in the attack and the following individuals were injured: Kemal Irmak, Huseyin Irmak, Mustafa Asal, Necati Vol, Ozgul Erdem Cosar, Bulent Cosar, Ozgur Cosar.
scite1: "Two Police Officers and One Civilian Killed in Terrorist Attacks, Turkish Daily, July 22, 1999.

location: This incident occurred at a petrol station near Solhan on the road to Bingol.
summary: 07/22/1999: Suspected gunmen from the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK), armed with automatic weapons, opened fire on a gas station near Solhan in the southeastern province of Bingol, Turkey, killing three people and seriously injuring a fourth. There was minor damage to the area from this attack.
target1: An unnamed gas station near Solhan, Turkey
motive: The attack was in retaliation for the capture of PKK member Cevat Soysal by Turkish forces.
scite1: "Terrorists Fire at Gas Station, Kill 3, Wound 1, Ankara Anatolia, July 23, 1999.
scite2: "Four Killed in two Terrorist Attacks in Turkey, Agence France Presse, July 23, 1999.

summary: 07/22/1999: Unidentified assailants entered the house of a handicapped man and shot him in the head in Anatolia, Turkey. A Maoist underground group, the Turkish Peasants and Workers Liberation Army (TIKKO), was suspected of killing the man.
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Four Killed in two Terrorist Attacks in Turkey, Agence France Pressee, July 23, 1999.

summary: 07/25/1999: Members of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) staged an armed attack against security forces in Akpinar, Turkey, killing two soldiers and injuring two others.
target1: Turkish Security Forces in Akpinar, Turkey
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Two Turkish Soldiers Killed in Kurdish Rebel Attack, Agence France Presse, July 25, 1999.
scite2: "Two Soldiers Killed in Elazig Terrorist Attack, Ankara Anatolia, July 25, 1999.

location: This incident took place at a dam construction site just outside of Bulanik.
summary: 07/29/1999: Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) rebels used firearms to attack a military vehicle near Bulanik, Turkey, killing one soldier and wounding seven. There was also minor damage to the vehicle.
target1: Turkish Security Forces on patrol in Mus Province near Bulanik, Turkey
motive: Unknown
scite1: "One soldier killed in Kurdish rebel attack in eastern Turkey, Agence France Presse, July 29, 1999.

summary: 07/30/1999: A total of four village guards were killed in Gurpinar, Turkey, when a group of perpetrators attacked the guards who were protecting the Telekom employees. Officials reported that the employees where the target of this attack.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Terrorists Kill 4 Village Guards in Van, Ankara Anatolia, July 31, 1999.

summary: 08/02/1999: A group of Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) rebels opened fire on a group of people returning home from the local coffee house in Cigdemli village, Turkey. Six villagers were killed and seven others were wounded in the attack.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Six villagers killed in Kurdish rebel attack, Agence France Presse, August 3, 1999.

summary: 08/05/1999: Armed members of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) attacked and killed an officer and wounded a soldier in Catak town, Turkey.
target1: Turkish military team in Catak town, Turkey
motive: Unknown
scite1: Turkish officer killed by PKK rebels, Xinhua News Agency, August 6, 1999.

summary: 08/06/1999: An explosive device was placed next to the wall adjacent to the door of the headquarters of the Socialist Power Party SIP at No. 2 Birlesmis Milletler Avenue in Konak District, Turkey. The bomb exploded at approximately 00:50 local time. The door of the building was damaged, but there were no casualties. It was noted that about one hour after the explosion, an unidentified individual called the 155 police emergency hotline and said that "he held the party members responsible for the fact that his younger sister had joined the party and that this is the reason he planted the bomb."
target1: Headquarters of the Socialist Power Party SIP in Konak District, Turkey
motive: An unidentified man called the police emergency line and stated that "he held the party members responsible for the fact that his younger sister had joined the party and that this is the reason he planted the bomb."
weapdetail: The explosive device consisted of a tube 20 to 25 cm long and 3.5 cm wide filled with 70 marbles and a quantity of gunpowder.
propcomment: The door to the building was damaged.
scite1: Bomb Explodes in Front of Party Building in Western Turkish City, BBC Monitoring Europe, August 6, 1999.

summary: 08/27/1999: An extreme-leftist militant carried out a suicide bomb attack 100 meters from a police check-point in Tunceli, Turkey. The man was a member of the Maoist Turkish Workers and Peasants Liberation Army (TIKKO). There were no other injuries in the attack, but the windows of some nearby buildings were blown out in the blast. Security forces detained another man who was suspected of being an accomplice of the dead militant.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The windows of some nearby buildings were blown out in the blast.
addnotes: This was the first suicide attack carried out by TIKKO.
scite1: Leftist militant killed in suicide attack in eastern Turkey, Agence France Presse, August 27, 1999.
scite2: Suicide Bomber Dies in Turkey, Associated Press Online, August 28, 1999.

location: Premiership Treasury and Foreign Trade Undersecretariat service building in the Istanbul suburb of Sisli
summary: 9/10/1999: A bomb exploded at the Treasury building in Istanbul, Turkey.   The building was badly damaged and 10 people were injured.  Seven members of the Revolutionary Peoples Liberation Party-Front (DHKP-C) were later arrested in connection with the attack and another one that occurred the same night.
target1: Premiership Treasury and Foreign Trade Undersecretariat staff and building
target2: Civilians in and around the Treasury building
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but authorities believe the attack was in preparation of "attacks against high level officials of public institutions and organizations"
weapdetail: The explosives were likely "industrially manufactured dynamite or explosives of the TNT type" and were detonated with "with cellular phone and remote control bomb mechanisms"
propcomment: A six-storey building was badly damaged
scite1: "1st lead: Twenty injured in Istanbul bomb blast," Deutsche Presse-Agentur, September 10, 1999.
scite2: "Experts investigating 10th September bomb blasts," Anatolia News Agency, September 11, 1999.
scite3: "Turkey: Bomb suspects captured in Istanbul," Anatolia News Agency, October 3, 1999.

location: Labour and Social Security Ministry building in Istanbul
summary: 9/10/1999: A bomb exploded at the Labour and Social Security Ministry in Istanbul, Turkey.   The building was damaged and 10 people were injured.  Seven members of the Revolutionary Peoples Liberation Party-Front (DHKP-C) were later arrested in connection with the attack and another one that occurred the same night.
target1: Labour and Social Security Ministry building and staff
target2: Civilians in and around the Labour and Social Security Ministry building
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but authorities believe the attack was in preparation of "attacks against high level officials of public institutions and organizations"
weapdetail: The explosives were likely "industrially manufactured dynamite or explosives of the TNT type" and were detonated with "with cellular phone and remote control bomb mechanisms"
propcomment: A bomb exploded in a government building
scite1: "1st lead: Twenty injured in Istanbul bomb blast," Deutsche Presse-Agentur, September 10, 1999.
scite2: "Experts investigating 10th September bomb blasts," Anatolia News Agency, September 11, 1999.
scite3: "Turkey: Bomb suspects captured in Istanbul," Anatolia News Agency, October 3, 1999.

summary: 09/28/1999: Unidentified assailants threw a petrol bomb at the Sisli Municipality water tank in Istanbul, Turkey. There were no casualties, but there was significant damage to the water tank.
target1: Susi Municipality water tank in Istanbul, Turkey
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The water tank truck was damaged in the attack.
scite1: "Firebombs hurled at Water Tank, DSP Office in Istanbul," Anatolia, September 29, 1999.

summary: 09/28/1999: Three unidentified attackers threw petrol bombs at the Democratic Left Party (DSP) office building in Istanbul, Turkey. No casualties were reported, but the building sustained minor damage. Informants reported that the assailants were chanting Union of Revolutionary Communists in Turkey (TIKB) slogans during the attack.
target1: Democratic Left Party (DSP) office in Istanbul, Turkey
gname: Union of Revolutionary Communists in Turkey (TIKB)
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The office buildings were damaged in the attack.
scite1: "Firebombs hurled at Water Tank, DSP Office in Istanbul," Anatolia, September 29, 1999.

summary: 10/01/1999: Two unidentified assailants hurled a firebomb into an unnamed bank branch in the Kagithane district of Istanbul, Turkey. No casualties were reported in the attack, but the blast caused minor property damage.
target1: An unnamed bank branch in Kagithane District
motive: Unknown
scite1: "AA Reports on Firebomb Attack on Istanbul Bank Branch, Anatolia, October 1, 1999.

summary: 10/02/1999: In Turkey, four unidentified perpetrators attacked Uskudar Headquarters of the Democratic Left Party (DSP), throwing fire bombs and leaving a banner of an unnamed illegal organization. Two policemen who gave chase and one attacker were wounded in an ensuing shootout while the other perpetrators escaped in a taxi.
target1: The Headquarters of the Democratic Left Party in Uskudar
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Four Persons Attack DSP Headquarters in Uskudar, Anatolia, October 2, 1999.

summary: 10/03/1999: Unidentified assailants hurled a firebomb at an unnamed bank branch in the Zeytinburnu District of Istanbul, Turkey. No casualties were reported in the attack, but the blast caused minor property damage to the bank.
target1: An unnamed bank branch in Zeytinburnu district
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Firebomb Hurled at Bank in Istanbul, No Casualties, Anatolia, October 4, 1999.

summary: 10/05/1999: Abdulcafer Turkoglu, a Turkish-born son of an immigrant from the Xinxianj province in northwestern China, murdered of Tang Xin in his restaurant, which was called Chinese Kitchen, in the Bakirkoy district of Istanbul, Turkey. Turkoglu was detained by police on October 9, 1999 and confessed to the incident. Turkojlu was also a known member of the East Turkestan Liberation Organization.
target1: Mr. Tang Xin, the owner of the Chinese Kitchen restaurant in Istanbul
motive: Turkoglu said he wanted to take revenge on China for testing nuclear and chemical weapons in Xinjiang and thereby killing his people. Turkoglus father had emigrated from Xinjian province, China in 1965.
addnotes: Police also detained nine people named by Turkoglu as having supported and bankrolled his activities in the East Turkestan Liberation Organization.
scite1: "Xinjiang Separatists held for Killings of Chinese in Turkey, Agence France Presse, October 9, 1999.

summary: 10/06/1999: At approximately 4:00pm local time, unidentified assailants hurled a firebomb at the local headquarters of Democratic Left Party (DSP) in the hamlet of Toroslar in southern Mersin Province, Turkey. No casualties were reported in the attack, but the blast caused minor property damage to the headquarters.
target1: The headquarters of Democratic Left Party (DSP) in Toroslar
motive: Unknown
scite1: "No Casualties in Bomb Attack on DSP Mersin Branch, Anatolia, October 6, 1999.

summary: 10/06/1999: Shortly after midnight local time, a handmade bomb was hurled at the local headquarters of the Idealists of the Nationalist Movement Party (MHP) by unknown assailants, causing only minor damage to the building and no injuries. The headquarters was located on Balikci Street, Islambey Boulevard in Eyup district in Istanbul, Turkey.
corp1: Idealists of the Nationalist Movement Party (MHP)
target1: Local headquarters of the Idealists of the Nationalist Movement Party (MHP)
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Police said the device was a simple handmade bomb.
scite1: "Bomb Hurled at MHP Idealist Club Causes Minor Damage, Anatolia, October 6, 1999.

summary: 10/06/1999: In a possible series of bomb attacks, an explosive was defused in the Sisli district of Istanbul, Turkey. The bomb was found inside a nylon bag, which was hanging on the iron bars in front of the passage where the Ministry of Justice is located. Authorities defused the time bomb without incident. The perpetrators of this attack were unknown.
target1: Turkish Ministry of Justice in the Sisli district of Istanbul
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device was successfully defused by authorities.
scite1: "AA Reports on Bomb Attacks in Istanbul, Anatolia, October 7, 1999.

summary: 10/06/1999: In a possible series of bomb attacks, Zografyon Greek Boys High School on Turanci street in the Beyoglu municipality of Istanbul, Turkey, was the target of a homemade bomb. The device had been left by assailants on the window of the dining hall of the high-school, causing some damage to the building, but no injuries. The Islamic Great Eastern Raiders Front (IBDA-C) claimed responsibility for the attack in a telephone call to the local Star newspaper.
target1: Zografyon Greek Boys High School in Beyoglu, Istanbul
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device was a homemade bomb.
scite1: "Foreign Ministry Condemns Attack on Greek School, Anatolia, October 7, 1999.
scite2: "Home-Made Bomb Explosion at Greek School in Turkey, Athens News Agency, October 7, 1999.

summary: 10/06/1999: In a possible series of bomb attacks, an explosive device was placed on the 7th floor of the Public Works and Settlement Provincial Directorate in the Besiktas district of Istanbul, Turkey. No one was reported injured, but windows of the building were broken by the blast. The perpetrators of this incident were unknown.
corp1: Public Works and Settlement Provincial Directorate
target1: Public Works and Settlement Provincial Directorate in the Besiktas district of Istanbul
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device was placed on the 7th floor of the building.
scite1: "AA Reports on Bomb Attacks in Istanbul, Anatolia, October 7, 1999.

summary: 10/06/1999: In a possible series of bomb attacks, a device exploded on the second floor of the the Economic Development Foundation (IKV) Center in the Sisli district of Istanbul, Turkey, slightly injuring eight people. The perpetrators of this incident were unknown.
target1: Economic Development Foundation (IKV) Center in the Sisli district of Istanbul
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device was placed on the 2nd floor of the building.
scite1: "AA Reports on Bomb Attacks in Istanbul, Anatolia, October 7, 1999.

summary: 10/12/1999: Unidentified assailants hurled a pipebomb at the local headquarters of the Nationalist Movement Party (MHP) in the Kucukkoy district of Istanbul, Turkey. No casualties were reported in the attack, but explosion caused minor property damage to the headquarters.
target1: The headquarters of the Nationalist Movement Party (MHP)
motive: Unknown
scite1: "No Casualties in Bomb Attack on MHP Istanbul Branch, Anatolia, October 12, 1999.

summary: 10/12/1999: Four members of the Turkish Workers and Peasant Liberation Army (TKP/ML-TIKKO) opened fire with rifles on Mesepinari village in Samsun Province, Turkey. Before fleeing, the perpetrators set fire to one house, which belonged to the father of Prof. Dr. Kurtman Ersanli from the University of Ondokuzmayis. No casualties were reported in this incident.
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Terrorists Attack Samsun Village, Anatolia, October 13, 1999.

summary: 10/12/1999: At approximately 4:00am local time, shots were fired from a car by unknown perpetrators at the Dogan Media Center in Bagcilar, Turkey. One bullet hit the office of Mehmet Y. Yilmaz, editor of the newspaper, Radikal. No one was injured in the attack, which caused only minor damage.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: This attack was criticized in a number of statements, including those by Abdullah Eksioglu, General Secretary of the Press Council, Turkish President Süleyman Demirel, Parliament Speaker Yildirim Akbulut, and Ismet Demirdogen, leader of the Contemporary Journalists Association.
scite1: "Turkey: Shots Fired at Dogan Media Center, Istanbul Hurriyet, October 13, 1999.

summary: 10/14/1999: At approximately 10:30 pm local time, unknown assailants plant a bomb in front of the Etibank s branch office in Ataturk district in Ikitelli Distrtic, Istanbul,  Turkey. The windows of the office were broken when the bomb detonated, but no one was injured. Police detained an unspecified number of suspects, but no further information on these individuals was not disclosed.
target1: Etibank s branch office in Ikitelli
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Bomb Placed in Front of Bank in Istanbul Causes Damage, Anatolia,October 14, 1999.

summary: 10/18/1999: Unknown perpetrators set a Greek citizens house on fire in the village of Bademli on Gokceada island, Turkey. A small child died in the fire.
target1: The house of a Greek citizen in Bademli village
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Foreign Ministry on Despicable Attack on Greeks Home, Anatolia, October 18, 1999.

summary: 10/20/1999: Unidentified assailants hurled a bomb at a police station in Maltepe district of Istanbul, Turkey. The bomb exploded, breaking the windows of the police station, but causing no injuries.
target1: A police station in Maltepe district, Istanbul
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Bomb Attack on Istanbul Police Station Causes Damage, Anatolia, October 21, 1999.

summary: 10/21/1999: Ahmet Taner Kislali, a prominent, pro-secular Turkish professor, former public figure and columnist for the leftist daily, Cumhuriyet (Republic), was killed when a bomb left on his car exploded in front of his home in the Cayyolu suburb of Ankara, Turkey. Kislali initially lost his left arm when the bomb exploded as he tried to remove the plastic bag holding the device from the windshield of his car. He died before arriving at the hospital. Kislali served both as Culture Minister and a member of Parliament in the 1970s. The Islamic Great Eastern Raiders Front (IBDA-C) claimed responsibility for the incident, which was carried out because the Professor often used his column to criticize Islamic fundamentalism. Two suspects were apprehended, but specific information on them was not disclosed in reports.
target1: Ahmet Taner Kislali, a political science professor, former public figure and columnist for the Cumhuriyet (Republic)
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Kislali often used his column to criticize Islamic fundamentalism, including an article published the week of his death, in which he denounced Turkeys leaders for tolerating religious fundamentalism.
scite1: "Car Bomb Kills Prominent Professor in Turkey, The Associated Press, October 21, 1999.
scite2: "With Turkey-Intellectual Killed Recent Assasinations (sic) of Secular Turkish int (sic), The Associated Press, October 21, 1999.
scite3: "Turkish Famous Columnist Killed in Bomb Attack, Xinhua, October 21, 1999.

summary: 11/18/1999: Unidentified assailants of the Great East Islamic Raiders Front (IBDA-C) damaged pictures of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk and planted a pipe-bomb in headquarters of the Ataturk Association (ADD) in Istanbul, Turkey. The perpetrators spray painted their name at the scene. No casualties were reported.
target1: Uskudar headquarters of the Ataturk Association (ADD)
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Major financial damage (unspecified) was reported as a result of the bombing.
scite1: "Bomb Attack at Ataturk Association Uskudar Headquarters," Ankara Anatolia, November 18,1999.

location: The incident occurred at the Atakoy Marina in the Bakirkoy area of the city.
summary: 11/25/1999: Nihat Akgun, a businessman who was the owner of Akgun Hotel, was killed in an armed attack in Istanbul, Turkey. Two unknown assailants attacked him at Atakoy Marina. No further information was provided.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Businessman Akgun Dies From Armed Attack Wounds," Ankara Antaolia, November 26, 1999.
scite2: Businessman Akgun Wounded in Istanbul Armed Attack, Ankara Anatolia, November 25, 1999.

summary: 12/19/1999: A homemade pipe bomb exploded at a stand selling alcohol at the Carrefour shopping mall in Istanbul, Turkey, injuring one civilian. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack. Police suspicion fell on radical Islamic groups because an alcohol stand was targeted.
target1: Stand selling alcohol at the Carrefour shopping mall in Istanbul, Turkey
motive: Unknown
scite1: Bomb Blast in Shopping Mall Raises Questions About Safety, Turkish Daily News, December 21, 1999.
scite2: Bomb Explosions Cause Panic in Istanbul Shopping Mall, The Associated Press, December 19, 1999.
scite3: Bomb Explodes in Turkey Mall, Associated Press Online, December 19, 1999.

summary: 12/19/1999: A homemade pipe bomb exploded under a tree near the Carrefour shopping mall in the Kadikoy district of Istanbul, Turkey. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attacks. Police suspicion fell on radical Islamic groups because an alcohol stand was targeted.
target1: Carrefour shopping mall in Istanbul, Turkey
motive: Unknown
scite1: Bomb Blast in Shopping Mall Raises Questions About Safety, Turkish Daily News, December 21, 1999.
scite2: Bomb Explosions Cause Panic in Istanbul Shopping Mall, The Associated Press, December 19, 1999.
scite3: Bomb Explodes in Turkey Mall, Associated Press Online, December 19, 1999.

summary: 12/25/1999: A pipe-type concussion bomb exploded at the Kanal D television building in the Mecidiyekoy quarter in Istanbul, Turkey. There were no casualties reported. An unidentified individual telephoned Kanal D after the attack to claim responsibility for the incident on behalf of a fundamentalist terrorist organization. The executive editor of Channel-D, Tuncay Ozkan, said the attack came in response to an announcement by the channel that it would no longer report on any "terrorist" attacks. The anonymous caller reminded Channel-D of its pledge not to report on any terrorist attacks and said, "Now, lets see whether you report this attack on you." A person said to be one of the two perpetrators, Ali Acar, was caught in Besiktas and reported to be a member of the illegal organization Great East Islamic RaidersFront (IBDA-C) - Islami Buyuk.
target1: Kanal D Television building in the Mecidiyekoy quarter in Istanbul, Turkey
motive: The attack likely occurred because Channel-D announced it would no longer report on any "terrorist" attacks.
weapdetail: Authorities reported a pipe-type concussion bomb was used in the attack.
scite1: Turkey: Kanal D Bomb Attack Suspect IBDA/C Member, Ankara Anatolia, December 26, 1999.
scite2: Bomb Thrown at Channel-D Building, No Casualties, Turkish Daily News, December 27, 1999.
scite3: Turkey: One Caught, Fundamentalists Reported Behind Bomb Attack, TRT TV, December 26, 1999.

summary: 09/06/2000: Unknown gunmen attacked Turkish Gendarmes (Turkish Ministry of Internal Affairs Security Forces) unit who were returning from an operation in Turhal District, Tokat Province. There were no reports of arrests.

Tokat Province is in north-central Turkey. News sources reported that the perpetrators acted in protest of "F-type" prisons (a type of maximum-security prison) in Turkey.

location: Istiklal Street, near Taksim square

Taksim square was full of people celebrating the new year when the bomb exploded.  Ten people were injured in the attack and the remaining crowds fled in panic.  Authorities speculate that the attack may have been retaliatory for a recent crackdown on jail-based hunger strikes.
